sector: Computer Systems Design and Related Services

sector_context.sector_name: Computer Systems Design and Related Services

current_state_2026.wage_growth: +5.0% YoY (classic Baumol squeeze: wages rising, employment flat)
current_state_2026.emp_growth: -0.4% (first decline signal after decades of growth)
current_state_2026.ai_adoption_level: growing_to_mature — this IS the AI workforce

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Custom Computer Programming Services
sub_sector_breakdown.vulnerability: HIGHEST — AI code generation directly targets core deliverable. 25-40% of Google code AI-generated. GitHub Copilot 20M+ users. 84% of developers using AI coding tools daily.
sub_sector_breakdown.transformation_thesis: Custom programming is the Baumol cure epicenter. $182B annual payroll at 2.26x economy average with the highest direct AI substitution potential of any professional sub-sector.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Computer Systems Design Services
sub_sector_breakdown.vulnerability: MODERATE — systems architecture requires tacit cognitive judgment that AI augments but does not replace. However, the implementation layer (configuration, deployment) is highly automatable.
sub_sector_breakdown.transformation_thesis: Barbell split: senior architects become more valuable (AI-augmented design), junior implementers face displacement.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Computer Facilities Management Services
sub_sector_breakdown.vulnerability: HIGH — facilities management is routine-cognitive work (monitoring, patching, ticket resolution) that AI agents directly replace. AIOps already automating 30-50% of L1/L2 operations.
sub_sector_breakdown.transformation_thesis: Managed services compress to AI-first operations platforms. Headcount per managed environment drops 60-80% by 2030.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Other Computer Related Services
sub_sector_breakdown.vulnerability: MIXED — includes IT consulting, staffing, help desk, and integration services. Staffing intermediation (P-027) is most vulnerable; strategic consulting is less exposed.
sub_sector_breakdown.transformation_thesis: IT staffing/body shop model faces structural collapse. Strategic consulting shifts to AI-implementation advisory.

size_distribution.solo_and_micro_1to4: ~250,000 establishments (62% of all firms, <10% of employment)

industry_structure.key_insight: The sector is structured as a massive long tail: 250K+ solo/micro IT consultants and small shops alongside global giants (Accenture, Infosys, TCS). AI disruption hits the long tail first — solo consultants doing custom development, integration, and support lose their cost advantage when AI tools can replicate their output.

india_it_services.fy26_fresher_hiring: 82,000 planned (TCS 20K, Infosys 20K, HCLTech 12K, Wipro 12K) — down from 150K+ in FY22 peak
india_it_services.ai_training_scale: TCS: 275,000 employees in AI upskilling. Infosys: 300+ enterprise-grade AI agents deployed. Wipro: AI-first strategy.
india_it_services.structural_shift: India IT hiring model fundamentally changing — from volume hiring of freshers to selective AI-skilled experienced hires. Revenue growth without proportionate headcount increase (Infosys CEO: 5-15% productivity gains from AI agents).
india_it_services.h1b_impact: $100K fee for H-1B employers + wage-weighted lottery effective Feb 27, 2026. IT services sector faces $500M+ annual cost increase. Accelerates India onshore-to-offshore shift.
india_it_services.key_risk: India IT services employs 5.4M workers and is the largest single employer in the global IT services value chain. AI-driven productivity gains mean revenue can grow while headcount stagnates or declines — the first time in the sector's 30-year history.

ai_coding_tools_landscape.adoption_rate: 84% of developers use AI coding tools, 51% daily

cursor.market_share: 18% and growing rapidly (from <20% to ~40% of AI PRs in 10 months)
cursor.growth_trajectory: Fastest-growing AI coding tool by adoption velocity

productivity_claims_vs_reality.claimed: 55% faster task completion (GitHub), 75% faster PR cycle (9.6d to 2.4d), 15-25 hours saved/month
productivity_claims_vs_reality.reality_check: Experienced devs 19% SLOWER on complex tasks (METR study). 30% acceptance rate on suggestions. Gains concentrated in boilerplate/testing, NOT architecture/debugging.
productivity_claims_vs_reality.key_insight: Productivity gains are REAL but narrower than claimed. AI excels at routine coding (boilerplate, tests, documentation) but struggles with complex architecture, debugging, and system design. This maps perfectly to Barbell classification: routine coding collapses, architectural judgment becomes premium.

vibe_coding_emergence.definition: Conversational, iterative app development where developers describe products in natural language and AI writes/refines code
vibe_coding_emergence.impact: Gartner: 90% of software engineers will shift from coding to AI process orchestration by 2027. MIT Technology Review named generative coding a top 10 breakthrough technology for 2026.
vibe_coding_emergence.threat_level: Creates a new class of non-developer software creators (designers, product managers, domain experts) who can build functional applications without traditional programming skills. Directly threatens the 250K+ solo/micro IT consultancies.

entry_level_collapse.manager_ai_preference: 37% of managers prefer AI over Gen Z hire
entry_level_collapse.entry_level_at_big_tech: Hiring at 15 biggest tech firms fell 25% from 2023 to 2024
entry_level_collapse.recent_grad_share: Only 7% of 2024 hires were recent graduates

layoff_statistics_2026.tech_layoffs_2026_ytd: 88 companies, 36,165 people (861/day pace as of Feb 2026)
layoff_statistics_2026.ai_anticipatory_cuts: 60% of orgs reduced headcount anticipating AI, only 2% tied to actual AI implementation (HBR/Oxford Economics)
layoff_statistics_2026.mckinseys_30pct: 30% of companies preparing to cut jobs due to AI

salary_trends.ai_engineer_premium: $170,750 mid-range (+4.1% increase) — AI specialists getting majority of salary growth
salary_trends.bifurcation: AI-specialized roles seeing 4%+ increases while general software engineering wages moderating to 1.6-3.5%

it_staffing_industry.structural_shift: 70% of tech leaders more likely to use staffing firms — but for AI specialists, not commodity developers. Staffing firms adopting agentic AI themselves (ManpowerGroup+Carv, Robert Half agentic AI).
it_staffing_industry.contract_preference: Clients preferring contract/project-based arrangements over permanent hires

IT staffing/body shop model (Robert Half, Randstad IT) structurally collapses as AI replaces commodity developer placement
Solo/micro IT consultancies (250K+ firms) face existential threat from vibe coding tools that let non-developers build software
India IT services (5.4M workers) pivot from labor arbitrage to AI arbitrage — revenue grows while headcount stagnates
Enterprise IT buying shifts from project-based (build us X) to product-based (subscribe to AI-platform Y) — 80.8% AI spending growth
Systems integration work compresses: what took a 5-person team 6 months can be done by 2 people in 6 weeks with AI agents
Junior developer pipeline collapse (67%) creates decade-lag leadership crisis: who leads engineering teams in 2035?
Managed services (541513) compress to AI-first operations: headcount per managed environment drops 60-80%

H-1B $100K fee + wage-weighted lottery effective Feb 27 — India IT cost structure increases, accelerating AI substitution
84% developer AI tool adoption becomes table stakes — firms without AI workflows lose bids
IT staffing revenues continue decline (-9%+). Robert Half and ManpowerGroup adopt agentic AI internally
Enterprise AI spending +80.8% YoY — IT services firms scramble to reposition as 'AI consultancies'
Entry-level IT hiring remains in structural collapse (67% junior dev decline persists)
2026.employment_projection: 2.40M (-2.5% from 2023 baseline). Net decline accelerating as AI tools mature and vibe coding expands addressable non-developer market.

events: Gartner's 90% AI orchestration prediction materializes: majority of software engineers spend more time prompting/reviewing than coding
First wave of small IT consultancy closures (estimated 30-50K of 250K micro-firms exit or consolidate)
India IT fresher hiring drops below 60K combined for Big Four (from 82K in FY26, 150K+ in FY22)
AI agents handle 60-70% of L1/L2/L3 IT support tickets autonomously
Enterprise shift from project-to-product accelerates — IT services firms with recurring revenue models survive, project-dependent firms struggle
Agentic coding (multi-step, autonomous development workflows) moves from pilot to production at large enterprises
2027.employment_projection: 2.30M (-5.2% cumulative). Small firm shakeout visible. Managed services headcount contraction accelerating.

events: Vibe coding creates 3-5x expansion of software creation (Jevons Paradox): more software being built by more people, but fewer traditional developers needed per project
India IT services complete pivot: revenue per employee up 30-50% from 2023, but total headcount flat or declining
IT staffing industry consolidates: major M&A wave as surviving firms acquire specialized AI placement capabilities
Solo/micro consultancy count drops from 250K to ~150K (40% attrition over 2026-2028)
Senior software architects and AI engineers command 2x premium over general developers (Barbell widens)
2028.employment_projection: 2.15M (-12.5% cumulative from 2023). Jevons expansion creates new roles (AI orchestrators, prompt engineers, AI quality assurance) but at 1:3 replacement ratio.

events: AI agents capable of end-to-end application development for standard business applications (CRM, ERP, inventory, reporting)
Custom programming as defined today (humans writing code line-by-line) becomes a niche skill for edge cases and legacy systems
Enterprise IT departments restructure: 3-person AI-augmented teams replace 15-person traditional development teams
IT services industry revenue grows (Jevons: more software demanded) but employment continues to decline — productivity paradox resolves in favor of capital over labor
Managed services sector has 70-80% fewer human operators per environment than 2025
2029_2030.employment_projection: 1.95M (-21% from 2023). Revenue per worker up 40-60%. Industry revenue grows even as employment contracts — the clearest Baumol cure in the economy.

events: IT services sector has fundamentally restructured: ~2.0M workers (down from 2.46M), but industry revenue up 30-50%
The 'developer' role has been redefined: AI orchestration, systems thinking, and domain expertise are the core skills
India IT services sector stabilized at ~4.5M workers (down from 5.4M peak) but with 2x revenue per employee
IT staffing industry consolidated to 40% of 2025 firm count
New category: 'AI Systems Consultancy' has emerged as the successor to traditional IT consulting
2031.employment_projection: ~2.0M (-19% from 2023 peak). But new adjacent roles (AI operations, AI governance, AI quality) partially offset. Net sector employment including adjacencies: ~2.2M.

routine_cognitive_tasks: Writing boilerplate code (CRUD operations, API integrations, form validation)
barbell_classification.net_effect: Routine cognitive middle (55%) faces 60-80% AI substitution by 2031. Tacit cognitive (40%) becomes premium — architects, security specialists, AI strategists see 30-50% wage increases. Net employment drops ~20% but revenue per worker rises 40-60%. The most dramatic Barbell split in any service sector because the workers ARE the AI experts — they see the disruption coming and are simultaneously building the tools that replace their colleagues.
barbell_classification.unique_dynamic: This is the ONLY sector where the disrupted workforce is also the disrupting workforce. Senior IT professionals are building the AI tools that eliminate junior IT roles. This creates a unique psychological dynamic: simultaneous empowerment and existential anxiety.

second_order_effects: Entry-level pipeline collapse (P-037): 67% fewer junior developers means 67% fewer potential senior architects in 2031-2036. Who fills the tacit-cognitive premium roles?
Vibe coding democratization: non-developers building software creates 3-5x total software volume, increasing demand for IT operations, security, and maintenance even as development headcount drops

India IT services transformation cascades to: Indian education system (engineering colleges), Indian real estate (IT parks), Indian consumption patterns (4.5M well-paid IT workers is a massive consumer base)
IT staffing collapse cascades to: administrative services (NAICS 56), professional employer organizations, corporate training providers
Enterprise project-to-product shift cascades to: Accenture/Deloitte consulting model restructuring, systems integrator M&A wave, ERP vendor strategy pivots
Senior developer wage premium cascades to: further H-1B demand for specialized talent (counter to $100K fee intent), geographic concentration of high-wage IT work in fewer metro areas
Managed services compression cascades to: data center employment (fewer operators per facility), NOC/SOC staffing, MSP business model crisis

economic_force_quantification.current_sector_revenue_addressable: $366.8B total payroll + estimated $200-400B in non-labor revenue = $550-770B total sector revenue
economic_force_quantification.ai_cost_compression_target: 55% of work is routine-cognitive and compressible. At 60-80% compression, this represents $120-170B in labor cost savings
economic_force_quantification.jevons_expansion: At 5-10x cheaper software creation cost, demand for software expands 3-5x. New market: non-developers creating applications. Total software creation TAM expands from ~$770B to $2-3T by 2031
economic_force_quantification.net_economic_force: $120-170B in labor reallocation (routine cognitive compression) + $500B-$1T in new demand creation (Jevons expansion of software) = $620B-$1.17T in value creation/destruction/reallocation by 2031
economic_force_quantification.key_insight: IT services is unique: AI simultaneously COMPRESSES the cost of the sector's core output (software/IT services) AND EXPANDS total demand for that output (Jevons). Revenue grows while employment falls. This is the purest Baumol cure in the economy — decades of above-CPI cost inflation being released in 5 years.

fear_friction_profile.sector_name: Computer Systems Design and Related Services

detailed_assessment.economic_readiness_9: Technology is here NOW. 84% of developers already using AI tools. GitHub Copilot at 20M+ users. Vibe coding tools functional for standard applications. Enterprise AI spending up 80.8%. The economic case for AI adoption in IT services is overwhelming.
detailed_assessment.psychological_readiness_6: Higher than most sectors because workers ARE technologists — they understand AI capability better than any other workforce. But understanding creates a DIFFERENT kind of fear: not ignorant fear of the unknown, but informed fear of exactly what's coming. 60% expect AI to cut more jobs than it adds. 51% worried about own job. 1 in 5 knows someone who lost a job to AI.
detailed_assessment.gap_3_analysis: The 3-point gap is UNUSUAL for a tech-savvy workforce. It reflects the paradox: IT workers know AI better than anyone AND fear it more precisely because of that knowledge. They can see the specific tasks AI will take over. This is 'informed anxiety' — the opposite of the 'ignorant resistance' seen in healthcare or education.
key_friction_points: Identity crisis: developers whose identity is 'I write code' face existential redefinition to 'I orchestrate AI code generation'
Senior vs junior divide: seniors see augmentation, juniors see replacement. Creates intra-workforce tension
India IT workforce: 5.4M workers with families whose economic security depends on continued labor arbitrage model that AI undermines
Billing model friction: IT services firms bill by the hour/person. AI reduces hours/persons needed. Revenue model must transform.
Client trust: enterprises trust human IT consultants they know. Switching to AI-first delivery requires trust transfer.
detailed_assessment.resolution_path: Fear resolves through forced adaptation, not persuasion. IT workers adopt AI tools because competitors do. Billing shifts to outcome-based. The fear gap NARROWS from 3 to 1 by 2028 as the transition becomes undeniable — but not before significant workforce churn.
detailed_assessment.fear_driven_demand_created: $15-25B in AI upskilling, reskilling, certification, and career transition services for IT workforce by 2030. IT workers are the largest high-income workforce facing AI disruption — their spending on adaptation creates its own market.

existing_coverage: MC-V35-5415-001: IT Services Engagement Intelligence Platform (70.75) — FORCE_RIDER. Covers data-compounding thesis for IT engagement management. Does NOT cover: staffing disruption, vibe coding threat, India IT transformation, managed services compression, or the self-disruption paradox.
gaps_identified: NO AI-native IT staffing/placement model — the staffing canary (P-027) specifically targets IT placement intermediaries
NO vibe coding / AI-first development platform model — the 250K micro-consultancy disruption vector
NO India IT services transformation model — 5.4M workers, largest single workforce at risk
NO managed services AI compression model — 180K workers in facilities management facing 60-80% headcount reduction
NO IT workforce reskilling model — $15-25B fear-driven demand for career transition
NO small IT firm consolidation/rollup model — 405K establishments at avg 6 workers is the most fragmented high-wage sector
NO AI agent IT operations model — agentic AI replacing L1/L2/L3 support
NO outcome-based IT consulting model — replacing hourly billing with AI-augmented outcome pricing

model_cards.model_name: AI-Native IT Staffing and Talent Marketplace
model_cards.sector_name: Computer Systems Design — IT Staffing Sub-Segment
model_cards.one_line: AI-driven talent matching platform replacing IT body shops with intelligent placement, skills verification, and outcome-based billing
model_cards.macro_source: IT staffing canary (P-027) + AI coding tool adoption (84%) collapsing demand for commodity developers while creating surge demand for AI-specialized talent

demand_drivers: Robert Half -53%, ManpowerGroup -44% stock decline signals structural disruption in staffing intermediation
70% of tech leaders more likely to use staffing — but for AI specialists, not commodity coders
IT staffing aggregate revenue down 9% — larger firms suffering more than small/mid
Enterprise preference shifting to contract/project-based from permanent — favors platform over body shop
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Traditional IT staffing firms match resumes to job descriptions. AI can: (1) verify actual skills via code assessment, (2) predict project-role fit based on outcome data, (3) match at 100x speed with 10x better signal-to-noise. Current staffing markup (30-50%) is indefensible when AI does better matching.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: The staffing intermediary model is a textbook Coasean transaction cost artifact. When AI reduces matching costs to near-zero, the 30-50% markup on commodity IT talent becomes structurally unsustainable. Robert Half/ManpowerGroup stock collapses are the market pricing this in.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI-powered skills verification (live coding assessment, portfolio analysis, contribution graph analysis) replaces human recruiter gut-feel. Agentic AI can screen 1000 candidates in time a recruiter screens 10.
PE refinancing wall ($930B maturing 2026) pressures staffing firm economics. IT staffing firms carrying debt face margin compression from AI alternatives. Creates acquisition targets.
Entry-level hiring collapse (-67% junior devs) means staffing firms lose their highest-volume, highest-margin segment. Silver Tsunami in staffing firm ownership creates acquisition opportunities.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Dependent on LLM APIs and job board data feeds. Low switching cost between LLM providers. Multiple data sources available.

regulatory_contagion.notes: State-level AI hiring bias regulations emerging (NYC Local Law 144, Illinois AI Video Interview Act). EU AI Act classifies AI hiring tools as high-risk. Compliance cost is a moat for well-resourced platforms.

competitive_import.notes: Crowded: LinkedIn AI, Indeed AI, Hired, Turing, Andela, TopCoder all targeting AI-augmented IT placement. But none have captured >5% market share from incumbents yet.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: IT staffing is the leading indicator for broader professional staffing disruption. Success here transfers directly to finance, legal, engineering staffing.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Talent available — many displaced IT staffing professionals available. AI/ML engineers available from tech layoffs.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: IT hiring is partially cyclical — freezes during recession. But AI specialist demand is counter-cyclical (companies use downturns to invest in automation). Platform marketplace model with low fixed costs survives funding freeze.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 3-5x vs traditional staffing firm (AI matches at $50/placement vs $5,000-15,000 human recruiter cost)

SN.justification: P-027 canary confirmed (RHI -53%, MAN -44%). IT staffing revenue down 9%. 84% AI tool adoption means the skill landscape changes faster than human recruiters can track. The matching function MUST be automated. Baumol 2.05 on a $367B payroll base. T6 Jevons: at lower matching costs, companies hire for more projects (contract preference growing).

FA.justification: F1 (9 — AI matching and skills verification directly enabled), F4 (7 — PE pressure on staffing incumbents creates acquisition targets), F2 (6 — entry-level collapse reshapes talent demand). 3 forces, 1 very strong. T10 Coase: transaction costs of IT talent matching approaching zero.

EC.justification: AI hiring regulation creates compliance moat (NYC, EU AI Act high-risk classification — but delayed to Dec 2027). India IT H-1B impact creates cross-border demand. 6 funded competitors but none dominant. Leading indicator for broader staffing disruption gives first-mover advantage.

TG.justification: Window 2026-2028. Staffing incumbents are in structural decline NOW — not speculative. P-027 timing confirmed. H-1B changes effective Feb 27, 2026 create immediate market disruption. Medium crash resilience due to cyclicality. T5 turning_point: capital available, demand proven.

CE.justification: $5-20M capital, 6mo to revenue, 65% gross margins. 3-5x cost advantage over human recruiters. Platform model scales without linear headcount growth. Survives 18mo freeze. Marketplace network effects create compounding moat.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 74.25 >= 70.0 and FA 7.5 >= 7.0. Rides F1 technology force directly into staffing intermediary collapse.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $8,000-15,000 per placement (IT contractor, 20-30% markup on AI-verified talent vs 30-50% traditional)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $500-2,000 per placement (AI matching, skills verification, compliance automation)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $5,000-15,000 per placement (human recruiters, physical offices, manual screening)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2-3x — lower friction placement means companies engage contractors for smaller, shorter projects they wouldn't have staffed before
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: US IT staffing: ~$50B. With AI, addressable expands to $75-100B via Jevons (more, shorter engagements)

fear_friction.primary_friction: IT staffing recruiters fear their own obsolescence. Clients fear AI bias in hiring. Candidates fear algorithmic screening that misses their strengths.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Outcome data transparency (placement success rates, retention) builds trust. Regulatory compliance (NYC Law 144, EU AI Act) creates compliance moat that human-only processes can't match.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI hiring compliance tools — $2-3B sub-market by 2028

confirmed: IT staffing intermediary model is in structural decline (RHI -53%, revenue -9%)
AI coding tools adopted by 84% of developers (demand landscape changing)
Enterprise preference shifting to contract/project-based engagements
likely: AI skills verification outperforms human recruiter assessment for technical roles
Regulatory compliance becomes a competitive advantage (not just cost)
India IT services transformation creates cross-border talent marketplace demand
uncertain: Whether marketplace network effects create winner-take-all dynamics or fragmented market
Whether enterprise clients accept AI-matched talent at the same trust level as recruiter-referred
Speed of incumbent adaptation (Robert Half already building agentic AI)
unlikely: Traditional staffing model recovers to 2021 levels — structural decline is irreversible

falsification_criteria: IT staffing revenue stabilizes and grows >5% in 2026-2027 (staffing canary was false alarm)
Enterprise clients strongly prefer human-intermediated IT hiring despite 3-5x cost premium
AI hiring bias regulation bans automated screening entirely (kills the model)
Major incumbent (Robert Half, ManpowerGroup) successfully pivots to AI-first platform and captures market

model_cards.sector_name: Computer Systems Design — Custom Programming Sub-Segment
model_cards.one_line: Enterprise-grade vibe coding platform enabling non-developers to build, deploy, and maintain business applications via natural language
model_cards.macro_source: AI code generation (25-40% at Google) + vibe coding emergence (MIT top-10 breakthrough) + 250K micro-consultancy disruption + Jevons expansion of software creation

demand_drivers: Enterprise software backlog: average company has 3-5 year queue of software requests that will never be built at current dev capacity
Vibe coding named MIT Technology Review top 10 breakthrough technology 2026
Gartner: 90% of software engineers shift to AI orchestration by 2027
30% of Microsoft code and 25%+ of Google code already AI-generated
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: There are ~28M software developers globally but enterprises need 10-50x more software than developers can produce. Vibe coding expands the 'developer' pool to include product managers, business analysts, designers, and domain experts — addressing the supply gap at its root.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: T6 Jevons: when software creation cost drops 5-10x, demand expands 3-5x. The constraint has always been developer supply, not software demand. Vibe coding removes the supply constraint. The only question is WHICH platform captures the enterprise market.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: LLM capability at Opus 4.6 / GPT-5 level enables genuine natural-language-to-working-application conversion. Agentic coding workflows (multi-step, autonomous) make this production-grade, not just prototyping.
Enterprise AI spending up 80.8% YoY. Shift from experimentation to production deployment. Companies investing in platforms that reduce developer dependency.
Enterprise executives fear being left behind on AI transformation. Business users frustrated by IT department backlogs. 'Shadow IT' evolves into 'empowered IT' via vibe coding.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Dependent on frontier LLM capability (Anthropic, OpenAI, Google). LLM API costs declining 50x/yr which helps margin but creates vendor dependency.

regulatory_contagion.notes: Low regulatory risk. AI-generated code has no specific regulation. Enterprise governance and security are the main concerns, which are features (moat), not risks.

competitive_import.notes: CROWDED. Cursor, Replit, Bolt, Lovable, v0, Microsoft Power Platform, Salesforce Platform, plus every low-code vendor adding AI. However, enterprise-grade (security, governance, audit trail) is a smaller, more defensible segment.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Success in enterprise vibe coding transfers to government, healthcare IT, and other regulated environments.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires deep AI engineering talent (scarce) but also product design talent (available from tech layoffs).

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Enterprise software budgets are partially discretionary. But AI-generated software that reduces developer costs is counter-cyclical (saves money during downturn). Platform with paying customers survives crash.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 5-10x vs custom programming shop ($500-2,000/app vs $50,000-500,000 custom development)

SN.justification: T6 Jevons: software demand expands 3-5x when creation cost drops 5-10x. Enterprise software backlogs are 3-5 years long. 28M developers globally cannot meet demand. MIT named this a top-10 breakthrough. Baumol cure on $182B custom programming payroll. The structural necessity is overwhelming — the only question is timing and form.

FA.justification: F1 (10 — this IS the F1 technology force made product), F4 (7 — enterprise AI spending +80.8%), F5 (6 — executive fear of being left behind). 3 forces, 1 at maximum. This is the most F1-aligned model in the IT services sector.

EC.justification: Heavily competitive (8 competitive import). Cursor at 18% and growing. Microsoft Power Platform has distribution advantage. LLM API dependency (5 supply chain). Enterprise-grade security/governance is the defensible niche but crowded there too. EC is the weakness.

TG.justification: Window 2025-2027 is NOW. Late entry is fatal in platform markets. Frenzy phase — capital available but competition fierce. Medium crash resilience (needs $20M+ capital, may not survive 18mo freeze without revenue). T5 frenzy: move fast or be locked out.

CE.justification: $20-80M capital (high for this engine), 9mo to revenue, 75% gross margins. 5-10x cost advantage. But does NOT survive 18mo funding freeze without early revenue traction. Capital-intensive platform play that needs scale to win.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 71.5 >= 70.0 and FA 8.0 >= 7.0. Rides F1 technology at maximum force alignment.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500-5,000/month per enterprise seat (consumption-based pricing for AI compute + platform fee)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $50-500/month in LLM API costs per active user
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $15,000-50,000/month for equivalent custom development capacity (1 developer fully loaded)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 3-5x — at $500/mo, product managers build apps they would never have requested from IT. Total software creation volume expands dramatically.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: Current: $182B (541511 custom programming payroll). With Jevons: $550B-900B (3-5x as non-developers create software)

fear_friction.primary_friction: Enterprise IT departments fear losing control and relevance. Developers fear skill obsolescence. Security teams fear ungoverned AI-generated code. Legal fears IP liability of AI-generated code.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Enterprise governance layer (audit trails, security scanning, approval workflows) addresses IT/security concerns. Position as 'empowerment tool that extends IT reach' not 'IT replacement.'
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI code governance and security scanning: $3-5B sub-market by 2028

confirmed: LLM capability sufficient for standard business application generation (MIT breakthrough recognition)
Enterprise software demand far exceeds developer supply (3-5 year backlogs)
Developer AI tool adoption at 84% proves willingness to use AI in development workflow
likely: Enterprise-grade security and governance can be built on top of AI code generation
Non-developer users can learn vibe coding tools within weeks (UX design makes this accessible)
Enterprise budgets shift from 'hire developers' to 'buy AI platform licenses'
uncertain: Whether AI-generated code quality reaches enterprise production standards for critical systems
Whether liability frameworks for AI-generated code stabilize (who is responsible when AI code fails?)
Whether the market is winner-take-all (one platform) or fragmented (vertical-specific platforms)
unlikely: AI code generation capability regresses — the capability frontier only moves forward
Enterprise demand for software decreases — every business needs more software, not less

competitive_density.total_funding: $3B+ (Cursor, Replit, Bolt, Lovable, v0 plus incumbents Microsoft, Salesforce, Google)

falsification_criteria: AI code generation quality plateaus — frontier LLMs stop improving at code tasks for 12+ months
Enterprise security concerns prevent production deployment of AI-generated code (permanent sandbox)
Microsoft Power Platform or Salesforce Platform capture >60% of enterprise vibe coding market (incumbent wins)
AI-generated code liability creates insurance/legal costs that negate cost advantage

model_cards.one_line: AI-native managed IT services replacing human-staffed NOC/SOC with autonomous monitoring, remediation, and optimization
model_cards.macro_source: Managed services (180K workers) at Baumol 1.52 with 60-80% of L1/L2 operations automatable by AI agents. AIOps already automating 30-50% of routine operations.

demand_drivers: Enterprise IT environments growing in complexity (cloud, multi-cloud, edge) while MSP headcount cannot scale proportionally
AIOps already automating 30-50% of L1/L2 operations — trajectory to 70-80% by 2028
AI agents can handle 60-70% of IT support tickets autonomously by 2027
Managed services sector Baumol 1.52 — moderate but significant stored cost energy
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Current MSPs require 1 engineer per 50-100 managed endpoints. AI-first MSPs can manage 1 engineer per 500-1,000 endpoints. The economics gap is 5-10x. Cybersecurity talent shortage (3.5M unfilled positions globally) makes the AI alternative not just cheaper but necessary.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Monitoring, alerting, ticket routing, L1 remediation (restart services, clear caches, apply patches) are routine-cognitive tasks. AI agents are already doing this. The only question is how fast the MSP industry structure adapts. Cybersecurity talent shortage FORCES AI adoption — there aren't enough humans.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI agents can monitor, diagnose, and remediate IT infrastructure issues 24/7 at machine speed. OpenAI Frontier and Claude agent teams enable multi-step autonomous IT operations.
MSP M&A market is active — platforms acquiring customer bases and converting to AI-first operations. PE buying MSPs for customer bases, not workforces.
Cybersecurity talent shortage (3.5M unfilled globally). Silver Tsunami in MSP ownership (small firms, aging founders). Entry-level IT support pipeline collapsing with rest of sector.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Dependent on monitoring tool APIs and LLM providers. Multiple vendors available. Open-source monitoring tools reduce vendor lock-in.

regulatory_contagion.notes: CMMC, SOC 2, HIPAA, PCI compliance requirements create both demand (compliance automation) and risk (AI in regulated environments). Net positive — compliance is a moat.

competitive_import.notes: ConnectWise, Datto, Kaseya all adding AI. New entrants from AI-native startups. Mid-level competition.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: MSP transformation transfers to data center operations, cloud infrastructure management, and enterprise IT ops.

resource_talent_flow.notes: AI/ML talent scarce but MSP domain expertise widely available from displaced L1/L2 engineers.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Managed services are non-discretionary — companies cannot turn off IT operations during recession. Cost-saving value proposition is counter-cyclical. Recurring revenue model with 12-36 month contracts.

capital_assessment.capital_required: $3M-$15M (or acquire existing MSP for $2-10M and transform)
capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 5-10x per managed endpoint (AI vs human-staffed NOC)

SN.justification: Cybersecurity talent shortage (3.5M globally) makes AI-first managed services a NECESSITY, not a luxury. AIOps already at 30-50% automation. Managed services are non-discretionary. Baumol 1.52 with 180K workers — moderate stored energy but the talent shortage forces adoption faster than economics alone would.

FA.justification: F1 (9 — AI agents for IT ops), F4 (7 — MSP M&A wave), F2 (7 — talent shortage + Silver Tsunami). 3 forces, all strong. Cybersecurity talent shortage makes this an F2 play as much as F1.

EC.justification: Moderate competition (ConnectWise, Datto, Kaseya adding AI). Compliance requirements (CMMC, SOC2, HIPAA) create moat for compliant platforms. Supply chain risk low. India IT services firms entering MSP market creates import competition.

TG.justification: HIGH crash resilience — non-discretionary, recurring revenue. Window 2026-2028. Silver Tsunami creating acquisition targets NOW. Quick to revenue (3mo for acquired MSP). T5 turning_point with proven demand.

CE.justification: $3-15M capital (or acquire existing MSP for $2-10M). 3mo to revenue. 72% gross margins. 5-10x cost advantage. SURVIVES 18mo freeze. Acquire-and-modernize model (P-002) = immediate revenue from Day 1. Best capital efficiency in this batch.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 75.5 >= 70.0 and FA 7.5 >= 7.0. Strong CE 8.5 but SN 8.0 < 9.0 prevents STRUCTURAL_WINNER. The acquire-and-modernize pathway gives this the best risk-adjusted entry of the batch.

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $15-50/endpoint/month (AI monitoring, remediation, human escalation for complex issues)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x — at lower per-endpoint cost, SMBs that couldn't afford managed services now can. Market expands from 60% penetration to 80%+.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: US MSP market: ~$80B. With Jevons expansion to underserved SMBs: $120-150B

fear_friction.primary_friction: Enterprise IT teams fear losing visibility/control. MSP engineers fear job loss. Client concern about AI handling security-critical operations.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Hybrid model: AI handles L1/L2 autonomously, humans handle L3+ and security incidents. Transparency dashboards showing AI actions in real-time. Gradual trust-building over 6-12 months.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI operations oversight and governance tools: $1-2B sub-market

ConnectWise or Datto ship AI-native platform that incumbents adopt quickly (no switching needed)
Cybersecurity talent shortage resolves (pipeline of trained professionals fills gap)

model_cards.sector_name: Computer Systems Design — Fragmented Micro-Firm Segment
model_cards.one_line: Acquire and consolidate 5-20 person IT consultancies at 2-4x EBITDA, modernize with AI tools, extract 3-5x margin improvement
model_cards.macro_source: 405K establishments at avg 6 workers = most fragmented high-wage sector in economy. Silver Tsunami (52.3% of businesses owned by 55+) + AI margin improvement = classic rollup with technology kicker.

demand_drivers: 405,625 establishments with average 6.1 workers — extreme fragmentation ratio 0.165
Silver Tsunami: 52.3% of employer businesses owned by 55+, 58% have no succession plan
Micro IT firms cannot afford AI tool investment ($50K-200K/yr for enterprise AI platforms)
Clients increasingly demand AI-integrated IT services that micro-firms cannot deliver
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: 250K+ micro IT consultancies built around 1-5 expert individuals. When founders retire (Silver Tsunami) or lose competitive advantage (AI tools), these businesses either consolidate or die. No natural successor for a 4-person IT consultancy — the founder IS the business.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: T10 Coase + T8 Demographics: falling transaction costs favor either very small (solo AI-augmented) or larger consolidated firms. Mid-size IT shops (5-20 workers) are in the Coasean dead zone. Silver Tsunami provides the acquisition pipeline. AI tools provide the margin improvement. PE capital provides the funding.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: Silver Tsunami creates acquisition pipeline of 130K+ IT micro-firms (52.3% of 250K owned by 55+) with aging founders who CANNOT sell to individuals (who would buy a 4-person IT shop?). Rollup provides exit path.

AI tools enable consolidated firm to serve more clients with fewer workers. GitHub Copilot, Claude Code, AI testing tools create 30-55% productivity gains per developer. This is the margin improvement that makes the rollup economically compelling.

PE dry powder seeking middle-market M&A targets. IT services rollups are proven (Cognizant, Globant grew through acquisition). AI margin improvement gives PE a clear value creation thesis beyond traditional cost-cutting.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: No significant supply chain risk. Diverse client base, standard tools, multiple AI vendors.

regulatory_contagion.notes: Low regulatory risk. No specific regulation on IT services consolidation.

competitive_import.notes: Other PE-backed IT rollups exist (NWN+InterVision, Integris+TechMD). India IT firms acquiring onshore presence. Moderate competition for quality acquisition targets.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: IT services rollup model transfers to other fragmented professional services (accounting, engineering, architecture).

resource_talent_flow.notes: Acquired firms come with talent. Key risk: founder departure post-acquisition. Retention packages needed.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Acquired firms have existing revenue and client relationships. Counter-cyclical: recession drives founders to sell earlier. AI margin improvement provides cost reduction during downturn. Diversified client base across sectors.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 1.5-2.5x vs unconsolidated firm (shared services + AI tools + cross-selling)

SN.justification: Silver Tsunami (P-002) confirmed at 52.3% of businesses owned by 55+. 405K establishments at avg 6 workers is the most fragmented high-wage sector. 58% have no succession plan. These businesses MUST be acquired, consolidated, or die. T10 Coase: mid-size IT shops in dead zone between solo AI-augmented and large consolidated.

FA.justification: F2 (9 — Silver Tsunami primary driver), F1 (8 — AI margin improvement), F4 (7 — PE capital seeking targets). 3 forces all strong. The forces compound: demographics provide supply, technology provides margin, capital provides funding.

EC.justification: Low supply chain and regulatory risk. Moderate competition for targets (5 competitive import). India IT firms entering could compete for acquisition targets. Leading indicator for other professional services rollups.

TG.justification: HIGH crash resilience — acquired revenue from Day 1. Counter-cyclical acquisition pricing (recession = cheaper targets). Window 2026-2029 is wide. Time to revenue: 1 month (day-one acquired revenue). T5 turning_point with proven playbook (PE IT services rollups are a known model). Highest TG in the batch.

CE.justification: $10-50M for first wave. Day-1 revenue. 55% gross margin improving to 65%+ with AI tools. 1.5-2.5x cost advantage via shared services + AI. Survives 18mo freeze. Capital efficiency depends on acquisition pricing discipline — overpaying kills the model.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 76.0 >= 70.0 and FA 8.0 >= 7.0. Highest composite in the batch. The acquire-and-modernize + demographic force combination makes this the strongest risk-adjusted play in the IT services deep dive.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500K-$2M per acquired firm annually (existing revenue base)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: AI tool investment: $5K-20K per worker per year (Copilot, Claude, testing tools)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: Unconsolidated firm overhead: 35-45% of revenue (individual health insurance, no purchasing power, duplicated admin)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 5-8 acquired firms (shared services achieve scale, AI tools deployed)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x — consolidated firm can serve clients that individual micro-firms couldn't (larger projects, multi-site, 24/7 support)
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: 250K micro IT consultancies with combined revenue ~$100-150B. Top 10% by quality = $10-15B addressable for rollup.

fear_friction.primary_friction: IT firm founders resist selling their 'baby.' Employees of acquired firms fear job losses in consolidation. Clients fear losing personal relationship with founder.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Position acquisition as succession solution (founder gets exit, team gets growth opportunity). Retain founder for 12-24 month transition. Client relationships preserved via same team, enhanced with AI tools.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: IT firm succession planning and M&A advisory: $500M-$1B sub-market

confirmed: IT services sector is the most fragmented high-wage sector (405K establishments, avg 6 workers)
Silver Tsunami affects 52.3% of employer businesses
AI tools provide 30-55% productivity improvement for IT development work
PE IT services rollups have proven track record (Cognizant, Globant, NWN+InterVision)
likely: Aging IT firm founders will accept 2-4x EBITDA (limited alternatives — can't sell to individuals)

unlikely: Silver Tsunami reverses — demographics are irreversible
Solo IT consultants gain competitive advantage over consolidated AI-equipped firms

falsification_criteria: IT micro-firm founders refuse to sell at 2-4x EBITDA (succession gap doesn't create willing sellers)
Client retention post-acquisition drops below 60% (relationship loss kills economics)
AI tool productivity gains are less than 20% in practice (margin improvement thesis fails)
India IT firms undercut consolidated US firms on price, winning clients away post-acquisition

model_cards.model_name: IT Workforce AI Reskilling and Career Transition Platform
model_cards.one_line: AI-powered reskilling platform for 2.46M IT workers transitioning from code-writing to AI orchestration, architecture, and domain specialization
model_cards.macro_source: Entry-level extinction (P-037) + anticipatory displacement (P-036) + 84% AI tool adoption creating forced reskilling demand for the largest high-income workforce facing disruption

demand_drivers: 2.46M IT workers at $149K avg pay facing role redefinition — largest high-income workforce disrupted by AI
Gartner: 80% of engineering workforce must upskill for GenAI by 2027
India IT firms training at scale: TCS 275K, Infosys 300+ AI agents deployed — creating competitive pressure for US workers
Entry-level pipeline collapse (67%) means existing workers must reskill (no fresh replacements coming)
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Traditional boot camps and university CS programs teach how to write code. The new skill is AI orchestration — designing systems, writing prompts, evaluating AI output, maintaining AI-generated codebases. No scaled training provider for this transition exists.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: T25 Fear Economics: 60% of workers fear AI job impact. 51% worried about own job. 1 in 5 knows someone affected. IT workers feel this most acutely because they UNDERSTAND the capability. This fear creates $15-25B in reskilling demand. Fear is structural — the more capable AI becomes, the more reskilling demand grows.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: T25 Fear Economics: IT worker fear is INFORMED (they understand AI capability). This creates higher urgency and willingness to pay for reskilling than any other workforce. Fear is the demand driver.
AI-powered personalized learning paths, real-time skill assessment, and simulated work environments make reskilling faster and more effective. The technology enables its own antidote.
Entry-level collapse means companies must reskill existing workers (no fresh pipeline). Mid-career IT workers (35-50) face the most acute transition pressure.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Low dependency. LLM APIs for personalized learning, but content can be created and cached. Multiple LLM providers.

regulatory_contagion.notes: Workforce development is politically popular — likely to receive government subsidies, not regulation. WIOA reauthorization may fund AI reskilling.

competitive_import.notes: Coursera, Udemy, LinkedIn Learning, Pluralsight all adding AI courses. But generic platform approach vs. specialized IT-to-AI-orchestration transition is different. TCS training 275K internally = potential competitor AND validation.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: IT worker reskilling is the leading indicator for ALL knowledge worker reskilling. Success here creates playbook for finance, legal, healthcare workforce transitions.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Content creators available from tech layoffs. AI/ML instructors scarce but can be AI-augmented (meta: use AI to teach AI skills).

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Reskilling demand is counter-cyclical — layoffs INCREASE demand for career transition services. Fear is the demand driver, and fear increases during economic uncertainty. Subscription model with corporate and individual buyers.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 5-10x vs traditional corporate training ($500/course vs $5,000-20,000 per person for instructor-led reskilling)

SN.justification: 2.46M workers facing role redefinition is the largest high-income workforce disruption. Gartner 80% upskilling mandate. But reskilling platforms are not structurally NECESSARY in the Schumpeterian sense — workers could self-teach or companies could train internally (TCS doing exactly this). SN is moderate-high, not maximum.

FA.justification: F5 (9 — fear economics is PRIMARY driver), F1 (7 — AI enables better training), F2 (6 — entry-level collapse forces reskilling of existing workers). 3 forces, 1 very strong. This is the strongest FEAR_ECONOMY candidate in the IT services batch.

EC.justification: Moderate competition (Coursera, LinkedIn Learning, Pluralsight). Government subsidy potential (WIOA). India internal training (TCS 275K) validates demand but doesn't serve US market. Leading indicator for all knowledge worker reskilling.

TG.justification: Counter-cyclical (layoffs drive demand). Window 2026-2028. Quick to revenue (4mo). High crash resilience. Fear is increasing, not decreasing — timing gets better, not worse.

CE.justification: $5-20M capital, 4mo to revenue, 80% gross margins. 5-10x cost advantage over instructor-led training. Survives 18mo freeze. Platform model scales without linear headcount growth. Best gross margin in the batch.

model_cards.category_rationale: F5 psychology score of 9 is the primary force driver. Fear friction gap of 4 creates the demand. Composite 73.5 >= 65.0 for FEAR_ECONOMY. This model exists BECAUSE of fear — not despite it.

unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2-3x — at $500/year, IT workers who would never have paid $10K for formal training now subscribe. Companies that trained 10% of workforce now train 50%.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: 2.46M US IT workers x $1,000 avg spend = $2.5B US. Global: 28M developers x $500 = $14B. Plus corporate training budgets reallocation: $15-25B total addressable by 2030.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Workers unsure which skills to invest in (the landscape changes too fast). Corporate buyers unsure which training actually works (ROI measurement immature).
fear_friction.resolution_path: Outcome-based pricing (pay for skill certification, not seat time). Partnership with employers for placement guarantees. Real-time curriculum updates as AI tools evolve.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: This IS the fear-driven demand. The model monetizes the fear directly.

AI tool adoption at 84% creates forced skill evolution
Entry-level pipeline collapse means companies must reskill existing workers
India IT firms investing heavily in internal AI training (TCS 275K, Infosys agents)
likely: AI-powered personalized learning outperforms generic online courses for technical skill transitions
Corporate training budgets shift from generic to AI-specific reskilling
Government subsidies for AI workforce transition programs emerge (WIOA reauthorization)

Whether reskilling actually prevents displacement or just delays it

moat_sources: Employer outcome data (which skills lead to employment)
Real-time curriculum updates tied to AI tool releases
