falsification_criteria: IT workers self-teach AI skills effectively using free resources (no demand for paid platform)
Employers absorb all reskilling internally (TCS model becomes universal — no external platform needed)
AI tool evolution stabilizes (skills become static, reducing ongoing reskilling demand)
Coursera or LinkedIn Learning captures >50% of IT reskilling market (incumbent platform wins)

model_cards.sector_name: Computer Systems Design — Consulting and Systems Integration
model_cards.one_line: AI-augmented IT consulting firm billing on outcomes (working system delivered) not inputs (hours x people), achieving 3-5x delivery speed at 50% lower client cost
model_cards.macro_source: Enterprise IT spending shift from project-based to product-based + AI agent capability enabling 2-person teams to do 10-person team work + billing model disruption in $1.1T IT consulting market

demand_drivers: Enterprise IT spending up 10.8% in 2026, AI spending up 80.8% — but shifting from experimentation to production
Global IT consulting market: $1.09T growing 4.9% CAGR — massive TAM
AI consulting sub-market: $11.1B growing 26-36% CAGR — the growth vector within IT consulting
Clients increasingly demanding outcome-based pricing: 'deliver working system X for $Y' not 'send us N consultants at $Z/hour'
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Traditional IT consulting (Accenture, Deloitte, Infosys, TCS) bills by the hour or by the person. AI enables 3-5x faster delivery. But incumbent billing models PREVENT them from passing this value to clients (self-cannibalization). New entrants can price on outcomes and still earn higher margins.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: T1 Schumpeter: IT consulting incumbents cannot adopt AI-first delivery without cannibalizing their hourly billing revenue. A $200/hr consultant who becomes 3x more productive should bill $600/hr or complete in 1/3 the time. Neither is palatable to incumbents. New entrants price on outcomes and disrupt from below.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI coding tools (Copilot, Claude Code), AI design tools, AI testing tools enable 2-3 person teams to deliver what previously required 8-15 people. Agentic workflows automate integration, testing, and deployment.
Enterprise AI spending up 80.8%. VCs predict more spending through fewer vendors. Shift from 'try everything' to 'prove ROI' favors outcome-based models that guarantee results.

Enterprise executives fear being left behind on AI. CFOs want predictable costs. Outcome-based pricing addresses both: AI transformation delivered at predictable price. Resolves the fear-uncertainty gap.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Dependent on AI tool stack (Copilot, Claude, cloud platforms) but multiple providers available. No single vendor dependency.

regulatory_contagion.notes: Low regulatory risk for consulting delivery. Client-side compliance (HIPAA, SOX) creates opportunity for specialized compliance consulting.

competitive_import.notes: Accenture ($3B AI practice), Deloitte, IBM, TCS, Infosys all pivoting to AI consulting. But their BILLING MODEL is the vulnerability — cannot easily shift from hourly to outcome-based. Incumbent's dilemma.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Outcome-based IT consulting transfers to all professional services: legal, accounting, engineering consulting. First sector to prove the model.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Senior architects and AI engineers available from tech layoffs. Quality talent is scarce but accessible to well-positioned firms.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: IT consulting is partially discretionary — enterprises defer projects during recession. But AI-powered delivery at 50% lower cost is counter-cyclical (saves money). Outcome-based pricing gives clients cost certainty.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 2-3x vs traditional consulting firm (2-person AI-augmented team vs 8-person traditional team for same deliverable)

SN.justification: $1.09T IT consulting market with structural billing model tension. AI creates 3-5x delivery speed improvement but incumbent billing models prevent them from capturing it. T1 Christensen test: incumbents CANNOT adopt without self-cannibalization. But consulting is relationship-driven — structural necessity is high but not maximum.

FA.justification: F1 (9 — AI delivery speed), F4 (7 — enterprise spending shift), F5 (6 — executive AI anxiety). 3 forces, 1 very strong. The Christensen disruption dynamic (incumbent can't adopt without cannibalization) creates force alignment.

EC.justification: High competitive import (7) — Accenture, Deloitte, IBM all competing. Low regulatory and supply chain risk. Leading indicator for professional services transformation. But the market is CROWDED with well-capitalized incumbents that could pivot.

TG.justification: Window 2026-2028. Quick to revenue (3mo, first project). Medium crash resilience. Outcome-based pricing gives clients cost certainty (attractive in uncertainty). T5 turning_point. Enterprise AI spending shift provides clear demand signal.

CE.justification: $2-10M capital (low). 3mo to revenue. 65% gross margin. 2-3x cost advantage. Survives 18mo freeze (lean team, project revenue). Capital efficiency is a strength — this is a services business augmented by AI, not a capital-intensive platform.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 71.75 >= 70.0 and FA 7.5 >= 7.0. Rides F1 technology force into IT consulting billing model disruption.

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $10K-$100K per engagement (2-3 person team + AI tools for 2-8 weeks)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $100K-$1M per equivalent engagement (8-15 person team for 3-6 months)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x — at 50% lower cost, enterprises greenlight projects they would have deferred or cancelled. IT project backlog conversion increases.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: Global IT consulting: $1.09T. AI-addressable segment (standard enterprise applications, integrations, migrations): ~$300-400B. At 50% cost reduction: $150-200B in value reallocation.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Enterprise clients fear outcome-based pricing ('what if it costs more than quoted?'). IT decision-makers fear losing control to AI-driven delivery. Incumbent consulting partners fear margin compression.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Start with well-scoped projects (migration, integration) where outcomes are clearly definable. Build track record. Expand to more complex engagements as trust builds.

confirmed: AI coding tools enable 2-3x faster delivery for standard IT projects
Enterprise IT spending growing (10.8% in 2026) with AI spending leading (80.8%)
Incumbent consulting firms face Christensen dilemma with AI (cannibalize hours-based revenue)
likely: Enterprises accept outcome-based pricing for well-scoped IT projects
2-3 person AI-augmented teams can reliably deliver enterprise-grade systems
Enterprise AI spending shift from experimentation to production creates consulting demand
uncertain: Whether AI delivery quality matches human-delivered quality for complex enterprise systems
Whether outcome-based pricing model is sustainable (scope creep risk in consulting)
How quickly incumbent consulting firms (Accenture, Deloitte) pivot to AI-augmented delivery
unlikely: Enterprise IT spending declines — every projection shows continued growth
AI coding tool capability regresses — frontier only moves forward

falsification_criteria: Accenture/Deloitte successfully pivot to AI-augmented delivery within 18 months (incumbent adapts)
AI-delivered enterprise systems have significantly higher failure/rework rates than human-delivered
Enterprises refuse outcome-based pricing (prefer predictable hourly billing despite higher total cost)
Regulatory requirements mandate human oversight that negates AI delivery speed advantage

model_cards.sector_name: Computer Systems Design — IT Operations and Support
model_cards.one_line: Autonomous AI agent platform that handles L1-L3 IT support, infrastructure monitoring, and incident remediation with 80% automation rate
model_cards.macro_source: AI agents (OpenAI Frontier, Claude agent teams) reaching autonomous multi-step capability + 3.5M unfilled cybersecurity jobs + IT support cost at $15-40/ticket creating massive automation arbitrage

demand_drivers: 3.5M unfilled cybersecurity positions globally — cannot be staffed by humans alone
IT support ticket volume growing 15-20% annually as enterprise infrastructure complexity increases
Average IT support cost: $15-40/ticket (L1) up to $80-150/ticket (L3) — massive cost base
OpenAI Frontier and Claude agent teams enable multi-step autonomous IT operations
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Enterprise IT support requires 24/7/365 coverage across time zones. Human staffing for this is expensive ($80-120K/worker fully loaded) and talent-scarce (3.5M unfilled). AI agents can provide continuous coverage at fraction of cost while handling routine issues autonomously.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: IT operations is the DEFINITIONAL routine-cognitive task for AI: structured inputs (logs, alerts, tickets), known procedures (runbooks), measurable outcomes (resolution time, uptime). AI agents have demonstrated multi-step reasoning. The only barrier is enterprise trust, which is being overcome through hybrid deployment (AI handles routine, humans handle novel).

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI agents (Opus 4.6 agent teams, OpenAI Frontier) can now execute multi-step IT operations: read alert -> diagnose issue -> execute remediation -> verify fix -> update ticket. This is frontier capability unlocked in 2025-2026.

3.5M unfilled cybersecurity jobs globally. IT support workforce aging with entry-level pipeline collapsing (-67% junior hiring). The human workforce simply cannot scale to meet demand. AI agents are the only solution.
Enterprise IT operations is a $200B+ market. Cost reduction potential of 40-60% creates massive ROI that enterprise buyers are ready to invest in. AI spending up 80.8% YoY.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Dependent on LLM APIs for reasoning and monitoring tool APIs for data. Multiple providers available but agent capability requires frontier models.

regulatory_contagion.notes: SOC 2, HIPAA, PCI compliance for AI handling production systems. Compliance is both a requirement and a moat. Audit trails for AI actions are mandatory.

competitive_import.notes: ServiceNow, PagerDuty, Datadog all adding AI agents. BigPanda, Moogsoft (now BMC). Well-funded incumbents with enterprise relationships. But none have achieved 80%+ autonomous resolution yet.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: IT operations automation transfers to any structured operations domain: financial operations, manufacturing quality, supply chain.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires AI agent engineers (scarce) and IT operations domain experts (available from displaced workforce).

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: IT operations is non-discretionary. Cost reduction via automation is counter-cyclical. Subscription/platform model with recurring revenue. Cybersecurity compliance requirements create must-have demand.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 3-5x vs human-staffed IT operations ($5/ticket AI vs $15-40/ticket human for L1)

SN.justification: 3.5M unfilled cybersecurity jobs = CANNOT be solved by human hiring. IT operations is the textbook routine-cognitive AI use case. Ticket volumes growing 15-20% annually. Baumol cure on IT support labor costs. The necessity is near-maximum because the HUMAN SUPPLY DOES NOT EXIST.

FA.justification: F1 (10 — frontier agent capability directly enables this), F2 (8 — cybersecurity talent shortage is structural), F4 (7 — enterprise IT spending shift). 3 forces, 2 very strong. The F1+F2 combination (technology enables what demographics demand) is the strongest force alignment in this batch.

EC.justification: High competitive import (7 — ServiceNow, PagerDuty, Datadog all competing). Compliance requirements create moat for certified platforms. Supply chain risk moderate (frontier LLM dependency). Leading indicator for structured operations automation.

TG.justification: Window 2026-2028. Frontier agent capability just reaching production-grade (2025-2026). High crash resilience (non-discretionary). Quick to revenue once deployed (6mo). Time sensitivity high — first mover in enterprise AI ops captures data compounding advantage.

CE.justification: $10-40M capital (moderate). 6mo to revenue. 70% gross margins. 3-5x cost advantage. Survives 18mo freeze. Platform scales sub-linearly with customers. But requires significant upfront R&D for agent reliability.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 74.0 >= 70.0 and FA 8.0 >= 7.0. SN 8.5 approaches STRUCTURAL_WINNER threshold but EC 5.5 holds it back. The F1+F2 force combination (technology solves demographic deficit) is the core thesis.

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $1-5/ticket (LLM API + compute for agent reasoning + action execution)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $15-40/ticket L1, $40-80/ticket L2, $80-150/ticket L3 (fully loaded human cost)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x — at lower per-ticket cost, enterprises invest in proactive monitoring (catching issues before users report them), expanding total 'ticket' volume but reducing outage costs
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: Global IT operations market: $200B+. AI-addressable (L1-L3 routine): ~$80-120B. With Jevons (proactive monitoring expansion): $150-200B

fear_friction.primary_friction: CISOs fear AI agents making security decisions. IT managers fear losing visibility. Enterprise fear of AI 'going rogue' in production environment.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Hybrid deployment: AI agents handle L1-L2 autonomously, flag L3+ for human review. Full audit trails. Gradual trust-building: start with non-critical environments, expand as confidence grows.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI agent oversight and governance for IT operations: $2-4B sub-market by 2028

confirmed: AI agents can perform multi-step IT operations (proven by OpenAI Frontier, Claude agent teams)
3.5M cybersecurity talent shortage exists and is worsening
AIOps already automating 30-50% of L1/L2 operations in early adopter organizations
likely: AI agent resolution rate reaches 70-80% for routine IT operations by 2028
Enterprise trust in AI agents for production operations grows as track record builds
Compliance frameworks (SOC 2, CMMC) adapt to accommodate AI-operated IT environments
uncertain: Whether AI agents can handle novel security incidents (zero-day exploits, APT attacks)
Speed of incumbent platform AI adoption (ServiceNow has distribution advantage)
Whether enterprise adoption follows gradual trust-building or rapid deployment
unlikely: Cybersecurity talent shortage resolves naturally (opposite: worsening)
IT infrastructure complexity decreases (opposite: multi-cloud increases it)
AI agent capability regresses (frontier only moves forward)

competitive_density.total_funding: $800M+ (Shoreline.io, Resolve.ai, plus incumbent platform AI features from ServiceNow, PagerDuty)
moat_sources: Operational data compounding (every resolved ticket improves the model)

falsification_criteria: AI agent reliability plateaus below 60% autonomous resolution (not enough to change economics)
Major AI-caused outage creates enterprise backlash and regulatory response prohibiting autonomous IT ops
ServiceNow ships AI agent capability that incumbents adopt without switching platforms
Cybersecurity talent shortage resolves through training pipeline expansion (removes demographic force)

model_cards.model_name: India IT Services AI Transformation Enabler
model_cards.sector_name: Computer Systems Design — India IT Services Transformation
model_cards.one_line: AI platform enabling India IT services firms (TCS, Infosys, Wipro + 5K mid-tier) to transform from labor arbitrage to AI-augmented delivery, increasing revenue per employee 2-3x
model_cards.macro_source: India IT services (5.4M workers, $245B revenue) pivoting from 'send people' to 'send AI-augmented people' under pressure from H-1B cost increases, AI coding tools, and client demand for outcome-based delivery

demand_drivers: India IT services: 5.4M workers, $245B revenue — world's largest IT workforce
H-1B $100K fee + wage-weighted lottery effective Feb 27, 2026 — $500M+ annual cost increase for IT services sector
TCS training 275K workers on AI. Infosys deploying 300+ enterprise AI agents. Industry-wide AI transformation underway.
India zero-tax-through-2047 + $70-100B hyperscaler commitments position India as AI compute hub
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: India IT firms need to transform 5.4M workers from manual coding to AI-augmented delivery. Internal training programs (TCS 275K) address some demand, but a scalable, enterprise-grade AI platform for Indian IT delivery would serve the entire ecosystem — Big Four + 5,000+ mid-tier firms.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: India IT services model is built on labor arbitrage (cheap engineers). AI collapses that arbitrage by making ALL engineers more productive. The only survival path is AI-augmented delivery that increases revenue per employee. H-1B cost increases accelerate the transition. India's government is betting the economy on AI (zero-tax, hyperscaler commitments). The transformation is happening — the question is whether a platform captures it.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI coding tools, AI testing, AI documentation enable Indian IT firms to deliver 2-3x more output per engineer. This is the TECHNOLOGY that transforms the labor arbitrage model.

H-1B cost increases ($100K fee), India zero-tax-through-2047, $70-100B hyperscaler investments, US-China bifurcation making India a neutral technology hub. Geopolitical forces COMPEL India IT transformation.

India's demographic dividend (1.44B population, median age 28, 1B working-age) is an asset ONLY if the workforce transforms to AI-augmented delivery. Without transformation, the demographic dividend becomes a liability.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Dependent on LLM APIs (likely US-based: OpenAI, Anthropic, Google). India's AI compute build-out reduces dependency over time. DeepSeek/open-source provides alternative.

regulatory_contagion.notes: India's aggressively permissive AI regulation (zero-tax-through-2047) is a tailwind. US H-1B regulation creates demand pressure. EU AI Act creates compliance opportunity for India IT serving EU clients.

competitive_import.notes: Big Four (TCS, Infosys, HCL, Wipro) building internally. Accenture, Cognizant competing. But 5,000+ mid-tier Indian IT firms cannot build platforms internally — they need external solutions.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: India IT transformation is the leading indicator for global IT services transformation. Platform that succeeds in India can serve Philippines, Eastern Europe, LATAM IT outsourcing markets.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Indian AI talent pool growing (IIT graduates + startup ecosystem). Platform can be built in India using Indian talent at competitive cost.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: India IT services is partially cyclical (US enterprise IT budgets drive demand). But AI transformation is structural — firms that don't transform die regardless of cycle. Platform with recurring subscription revenue survives downturn.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: Platform enables 2-3x revenue per employee for client firms — massive ROI for buyers

SN.justification: 5.4M workers at $245B revenue MUST transform from labor arbitrage to AI-augmented delivery. H-1B cost increases accelerate urgency. But Big Four are investing heavily internally (TCS 275K training, Infosys 300 agents). The structural necessity is clear for the 5,000 mid-tier firms that can't build internally — less clear for Big Four who have resources.

FA.justification: F1 (8 — AI delivery transformation), F3 (8 — H-1B + India AI policy + US-China bifurcation), F2 (7 — demographic dividend at risk). 3 forces, 2 strong. The F1+F3 geopolitical technology alignment is unique — no other model in this batch has this combination.

EC.justification: India-specific opportunity with global transfer potential. Moderate competition (6). Strong regulatory tailwind (India zero-tax). Leading indicator for global IT services transformation (8). LLM supply chain dependency (5) partially offset by India AI compute build-out.

TG.justification: Window 2026-2028. H-1B changes effective Feb 27, 2026 create immediate urgency. Medium crash resilience (cyclical US enterprise spending). Quick to revenue for mid-tier firms (6mo). Time sensitivity high — Big Four internal solutions may lock in their ecosystems.

CE.justification: $10-30M capital. 6mo to revenue. 75% gross margins. Platform built in India at competitive cost. 2-3x revenue per employee uplift for client firms creates strong ROI argument. Survives 18mo freeze with recurring subscription revenue.

model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 72.25 >= 70.0 and FA 7.5 >= 7.0. The F1+F3 geopolitical-technology alignment is the unique thesis — India's AI transformation is a geographic-specific force rider.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500-5,000/month per engineering team license (10-50 engineers per license)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $100-1,000/month per team (LLM APIs, platform infrastructure, India data center costs)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: Internal build: $50K-$500K per firm (TCS-scale firms only). Mid-tier firms: cannot build at all.
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 200-500 mid-tier IT firm subscriptions (5% of 5,000 addressable firms)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x — at lower per-engineer delivery cost, India IT firms can serve smaller clients and take on projects they would have declined as unprofitable. Market expands.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: India IT services: $245B revenue. Mid-tier (non-Big-Four) share: ~$80-100B. Platform TAM: $5-10B (5-10% of mid-tier revenue captured as platform fee)

fear_friction.primary_friction: Indian IT workers fear AI replacing the labor arbitrage model that employs 5.4M people. Mid-tier firm owners fear dependency on external AI platform. US clients uncertain whether AI-augmented Indian delivery matches quality of pure-human delivery.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Position as 'workforce amplifier' not 'workforce replacer.' Show revenue per employee increases that fund higher wages for retained workers. Demonstrate quality improvement through AI (fewer bugs, faster delivery).
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: Indian IT workforce reskilling: $3-5B sub-market as firms invest in AI transformation training

confirmed: India IT services industry is investing heavily in AI transformation (TCS 275K, Infosys 300+ agents)
H-1B cost increases effective Feb 27, 2026 create $500M+ annual pressure
India government pursuing aggressively permissive AI policy (zero-tax, hyperscaler commitments)
likely: Mid-tier India IT firms (5,000+) cannot build internal AI platforms at Big Four scale
Revenue per employee can increase 2-3x with AI tools for standard IT delivery
India's AI compute infrastructure reaches sufficient scale by 2027-2028
uncertain: Whether Big Four internal platforms become ecosystem products (competing with this model)
Whether India-based AI platform can compete with US-based tools on model quality
Speed of mid-tier firm AI adoption (conservative vs aggressive)
Whether US-China AI bifurcation restricts India's access to frontier models
unlikely: India IT services industry returns to pure labor arbitrage model — transformation is irreversible
H-1B restrictions are reversed (political consensus supports restrictions)

moat_sources: Localized AI models (Indian English, technical vocabulary)
Compliance with Indian data localization requirements

falsification_criteria: Big Four (TCS, Infosys) open their internal AI platforms to mid-tier firms (incumbent captures market)
Mid-tier India IT firms adopt US-based AI coding tools directly (no need for India-specific platform)
US-India technology decoupling restricts frontier AI model access for India-based platforms
India IT services revenue growth stalls despite AI transformation (market pressure too strong)

model_cards_summary.top_card: MC-IT-004 IT Services Micro-Firm Rollup Platform (76.0) — highest composite, best risk-adjusted via acquire-and-modernize pathway
model_cards_summary.strongest_SN: MC-IT-007 AI Agent IT Operations Platform (8.5) — cybersecurity talent shortage makes this near-structural-winner
model_cards_summary.strongest_FA: MC-IT-002 Vibe Coding Enterprise Platform (8.0) and MC-IT-004 Rollup (8.0) and MC-IT-007 AIOps (8.0) — three-way tie
model_cards_summary.strongest_CE: MC-IT-003 AI-First MSP (8.5) — acquire-and-modernize model with day-1 revenue and non-discretionary demand
model_cards_summary.fear_economy_card: MC-IT-005 IT Workforce Reskilling (73.5) — fear is the demand driver, counter-cyclical
model_cards_summary.batch_vs_prior_it_card: MC-V35-5415-001 scored 70.75. New batch mean 73.6 (+2.85pp). Deep dive enables more precise scoring with sector-specific evidence.
key_patterns_across_cards: SELF-DISRUPTION PARADOX: The IT workforce is simultaneously the disruptor (building AI tools) and the disrupted (AI tools replacing their work). This creates unique psychological dynamics — informed anxiety vs ignorant resistance.
ACQUIRE-AND-MODERNIZE PREMIUM: MC-IT-003 (MSP) and MC-IT-004 (Rollup) score highest because they have day-1 revenue and proven demand. The acquire-and-modernize pathway reduces timing risk.
FEAR AS MARKET: MC-IT-005 (Reskilling) monetizes the fear directly. 2.46M high-income workers fearing displacement creates a $15-25B reskilling market.

TALENT SHORTAGE OVERRIDE: MC-IT-007 (AIOps) is nearly a STRUCTURAL_WINNER because the 3.5M cybersecurity talent shortage makes AI agents not just cheaper but NECESSARY. The human supply does not exist.

INDIA AS BELLWETHER: MC-IT-008 captures the India IT transformation that affects 5.4M workers. As the largest IT workforce globally, India's AI transformation trajectory predicts the global industry's path.
BILLING MODEL DISRUPTION: MC-IT-006 (Outcome-Based Consulting) targets the Christensen dilemma — incumbents cannot adopt AI-augmented delivery without cannibalizing their hourly billing model.
FRAGMENTATION AS OPPORTUNITY: 405K establishments at avg 6 workers. MC-IT-001, MC-IT-002, and MC-IT-004 all exploit this fragmentation from different angles (staffing, vibe coding, rollup).

sources: GitHub (Copilot 20M+ users, AI code generation statistics)
India IT financial results (TCS, Infosys, Wipro quarterly reports)
Robert Half/ManpowerGroup financial performance (stock decline, revenue data)
MIT Technology Review (vibe coding top-10 breakthrough)
V1_transformation_evidence_quality.leading_and_lagging_alignment: YES. Leading: AI tool adoption (84% developers), enterprise AI spending (+80.8%). Lagging: IT employment flat (-0.4%), staffing revenue down (-9%), junior hiring collapse (-67%). Both point same direction.
theoretical_alignment: T1 (Schumpeter — incumbents cannot adopt without cannibalization)
T10 (Coase — falling transaction costs kill mid-size)

specific_threshold_events: Feb 27, 2026: H-1B $100K fee + wage-weighted lottery effective
Mid-2026: Vibe coding tools cross mainstream adoption threshold
2027-2028: First wave of IT micro-firm closures visible in QCEW data
2028-2029: India IT fresher hiring drops below 50K (from 150K+ peak)
V2_timing_assessment.fastest_timeline: Employment drops 15% by 2029 (if AI agent capability accelerates faster than expected)
V2_timing_assessment.slowest_timeline: Employment drops 10% by 2031 (if enterprise adoption is slower, regulatory friction increases)
V2_timing_assessment.most_likely_timeline: Employment drops ~20% by 2031 (from 2.46M to ~2.0M) while industry revenue grows 30-50%

evidence_against_transformation: Experienced devs 19% SLOWER on complex tasks (METR study) — AI productivity gains may be narrower than assumed
30% acceptance rate on AI code suggestions — developers reject 70% of AI output
Enterprise AI deployment still mostly experimental — 78% adopted but few show EBIT impact
India Big Four hiring 82K freshers in FY26 — hiring is REDUCED but not eliminated
BLS projects computer and IT occupations to grow faster than average 2024-2034
Software developer shortage may be 40% worse in 2026 due to AI-driven demand (demand expands faster than AI replaces)
potential_reversal_factors: AI capability plateau — if LLMs stop improving at coding tasks, the transformation timeline extends significantly
AI code liability crisis — if AI-generated code causes major failures and creates legal liability, adoption decelerates
Regulation — if US federal or state regulation significantly restricts AI in software development or hiring
Enterprise trust collapse — if high-profile AI deployment failures create widespread enterprise distrust
V3_counter_evidence.counter_evidence_assessment: Counter-evidence is REAL but does not reverse the direction. The 19% slower on complex tasks finding confirms the BARBELL thesis — AI excels at routine, struggles with complex. This means the transformation is sector-internal reallocation (routine to complex) rather than total displacement. BLS growth projections may be correct on TOTAL employment but miss the COMPOSITION shift (fewer coders, more AI orchestrators, architects, and security specialists).

V4_unit_economics_validation.cost_assumptions: Based on current 2026 pricing (LLM API costs, AI tool subscriptions). Costs declining 50x/yr on inference improves economics over time.
V4_unit_economics_validation.jevons_precedent: Historical: desktop publishing expanded document creation 10x. Spreadsheets expanded financial modeling 5x. Web expanded content creation 100x. Software creation expansion of 3-5x from AI is conservative by historical standards.
V4_unit_economics_validation.break_even_realism: All 8 models have break-even volumes that represent <1% of addressable market. Conservative.

fear_friction_update_for_engine_state.sector_name: Computer Systems Design and Related Services
fear_friction_update_for_engine_state.notes: UNIQUE friction profile: IT workers have HIGHEST understanding of AI capability of any workforce, which creates INFORMED fear rather than ignorant resistance. Gap of 3 is moderate but the CHARACTER of the fear is different — precise, technical, and based on direct experience with AI tools. Resolution is FASTER than sectors with ignorant resistance because workers adopt out of competitive necessity, not persuasion. Fear creates a $15-25B reskilling market (P-037 + T25). Sub-sector variation: facilities management (gap 2, routine work, accept automation) vs custom programming (gap 4, identity crisis as 'coding' is redefined) vs systems design (gap 2, see AI as augmentation).

sector_transformation_update_for_engine_.sector_name: Computer Systems Design and Related Services
sector_transformation_update_for_engine_.evidence_summary: v3-7: NAICS 5415 deep dive completed. 2.46M workers at $149K avg (Baumol 2.05), 405K establishments (extreme fragmentation, avg 6 workers). Employment flat (-0.4%) while wages surge (+5.0%) = classic Baumol squeeze. 84% developer AI tool adoption. GitHub Copilot 20M+ users. Vibe coding named MIT top-10 breakthrough. Entry-level collapse: 67% junior dev hiring decline. India IT: 5.4M workers transforming from labor arbitrage to AI-augmented delivery. H-1B $100K fee effective Feb 27, 2026. IT staffing canary confirmed (RHI -53%, revenue -9%). 8 new model cards scored (mean 73.6, range 71.5-76.0). Key thesis: sector DISRUPTS ITSELF — the workers building AI tools are eliminating their own job categories. Employment projected to drop ~20% by 2031 (2.46M to ~2.0M) while industry revenue grows 30-50%. Jevons Paradox: 3-5x expansion of total software creation volume as non-developers gain vibe coding capability.
